newsitem.title: UK: Panalpina, IBM deal drives new cargo flights.
newsitem.headline: Panalpina, IBM deal drives new cargo flights.

text.p: Swiss freight forwarder, Panalpina Welttransport AG Holding is behind the launch of new Boeing 747-200 freighter flights from Manchester to the U.S, Panalpina president Switzerland, Herbert Grissemann told Reuters by telephone from Zurich.
Manchester Airport said on August 20 that Luxembourg-based Cargolux Airlines International SA had began operating scheduled Boeing 747-200 freighter flights from the airport to Hartford, Connecticut.
The aircraft is owned by Atlas Air and will fly under a Cargolux flight number.

Industry sources said they believed the flights were closely related to Panalpina winning a major airfreight contract from International Business Machines Corp. A three-year contract started on August 15, covering 35 to 40 percent of IBM's worldwide airfreight needs.

Asked why Panalpina decided to launch the freighter service he said: "The IBM contract represents substantial business. The UK has one of the least sophisticated cargo services to the U.S. Everyone flies bellyhold, the traditional airlines just do not consider operating their own freighters."
"The space is 100 percent Panalpina owned," Grissemann said.
The contract makes Panalpina the exclusive forwarder for traffic between Europe and the North Atlantic, Latin America, the Middle East and Africa, as well as U.S.-Latin America, Grissemann said.
He added these flights will not only be for IBM traffic.

Three flights will operate from Hartford Connecticut to Manchester and go on to Luxembourg. Leaving the U.S. on Fridays, Sundays and Tuesdays, the return journery will be made from Europe on Monday and Wednesday.
The Wednesday flight is an optional flight and will depend on cargo volumes.
A third return flight from Luxembourg will route Luxembourg-Hartford-Mexico City-Guadalajara-Miami-Hartford.
IBM also has plants near Hartford and in Guadalajara. Other large electronic companies including Hewlett-Packard Co have operations in the Mexican city.

Grisseman added: "We do not want to be an airline, we are a forwarder. We do not want to compete with the airlines we want to add services. Atlas Air provides the aircraft and the crew and Cargolux the know-how."
"In our vision for cargo bellyhold carriers are not our partners."
Panalpina also said on August 16 they had acquired privately-owned leading Dutch forwarder, ChartAir for an undisclosed sum.
The latter handles most of Philips NV airfreight business to and from the Netherlands, industry sources said.
